FacilityName: City of DuBois Sewage Treatment Plant

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Clearfield County Dept of Emer. Svc

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary:  The City of DuBois Wastewater Treatment Facility is
located just outside of the City limits in the neighboring community of Sandy 
Township.  The plant treats approximately three million (3,000,000) gallons of 
sewage per day.  The treated sewage is disinfected with chlorine prior to 
discharge.

The facility's approach to chemical safety includes training of facility personnel 
in proper handling techniques of toxic chemicals to lessen the risk of accidental 
releases and the facility is also equipped with a two (2) ton chlorine emergency 
repair kit.  Another approach is to maintain two (2), two thousand (2,000) gallon 
tanks of chlorine at the facility at any given time.  One (1) tank will be in use 
while maintaining the other tank in storage.

Chlorine is a toxic gas and hazardous chemical and the threshold amount of 
chlorine for preparing a Risk Management Plan (RMP) is two thousand (2,000) 
pounds per one process.  The treatment plant has a maximum of four thousand 
(4,000) pounds of chlorine at the site.  However, there is only one covered process 
that contains a maximum of two thousand (2,000) pounds of chlorine.

The covered process involves the use of one (1), two thousand (2,000) pound 
cylinder to disinfect treated sewage and the storage of one (1), two thousand 
(2,000) pound cylinder of chlorine.  Both cylinders are located inside the chlorine 
building on racks.  The chlorine building is equipped with the proper ventilation, 
alarms, and safety measures.  Since, the two cylinders are stored in close 
proximity to each other, they are considered only one process.  The maximum 
amount of chlorine stored in this process is four thousand (4,000) pounds.  Since 
it is more than the two thousand five hundred (2,500) pounds allowed, it is a 
covered process.

Because there is one covered process, the worst-case scenario and an alternative 
scenario were analyzed for potential off-site impacts involving the public sector.  
The worst-ca

se scenario considers the potential hazards if the two (2), two 
thousand (2,000) pound cylinders would release the entire contents of chlorine in 
a ten-minute period.  The analysis utilizing the EPA's RMP Com Computer 
computations assumes that under stable atmospheric conditions the gases would 
carry the farthest.  Based on this analysis, the off-site impacts to the four thousand 
(4,000) pounds of chlorine being released during the ten-minute period would 
range 1.9 miles from the treatment plant.  The estimated population affected 
would be approximately thirteen thousand (13,000) individuals.  The likelihood of 
the worst-case scenario becoming reality is remote considering the following 
factor: that with only one (1) cylinder in storage, that cylinder is only moved 
when the other cylinder is empty and is moved by a mechanical hoist system.  
Should the one cylinder rupture due to falling from the hoist, the second cylinder, 
which is empty, would not be affected.

The alternate release analysis is a more realistic assumption of a potential gas 
hazard occurring.  The most likely release would be the rupture of one tank by 
some outside force.  This analysis assumes that two thousand (2,000) pounds of 
chlorine is released in a thirteen (13) minute period.  It assumes that the 
atmosphere is not as stable and the gas would dissipate at a faster rate.  By 
utilizing the EPA's RMP Comp Computer Model, it is estimated that the off-site 
impacts would range within a 0.3 miles from the treatment plant.  A release of this 
type is estimated to affect approximately ninety-five (95) households and two 
hundred thirty-five (235) individuals.

To avoid accidents from occurring, the personnel are trained in proper procedures 
for moving cylinders.  The method for moving the cylinders is an automatic hoist 
system and several safety procedures are performed during the moving process:

1.	This moving operation is not performed alone.
2.	 When the hooks are attached to t

he cylinders, they are inspected to assure 
a secure connection.
3.	Before the cylinders are lifted the chains are inspected for loose links that 
could fail.
4.	The hoist is raised and moved slowly to prevent any jerking of the 
cylinder.
5.	The personnel are trained in chlorine leak repair to minimize the affects of 
a leak.
 
Due to the safety procedures already incorporated at the plant, there have been no 
accidental releases of chlorine gases over the past eleven (11) years.  The facility 
has an emergency response program in place and should a leak be 
detected, the facility operators will initiate an emergency response by notifying 
the local emergency Communications Center (Clearfield County Control).  The 
Center will then notify all the emergency responders and, if required, a public 
notification and evacuation plan would be initiated.  This would affect the local 
hospital and schools with plans in place for evacuation of these and similar 
facilities, if required.
